I [f.] too will tell queen Yaśodharā (that) with the noble Ānanda … (165)
The (lay woman) says: I too will go to meet the Buddha-god the teacher. – All leave. || The interlude
I [f.] too will go towards the Buddha, the teacher. (cf 165)
(has come to an end.) || ... surrounded ..., carrying the gold-colored cotton cloth in her hands the Śākya queen Mahāprajāpatī Gautamī ...
When is the time going to be, when I ... with the rank of Buddha ... this jewel of a garment ...
When is the time going to be, when I … with the rank of Buddha … this jewel of a garment … (165)
... lady, this royal (garden) of Nyagrodhārāma ... for the Cakravartin king with the rank of Buddha ...
... queen Gopikā, having looked with (eyes ...) at the Nyagrodhārāma, says: || In the Ratisupa [tune] ||
... he made glad (six)ty thousand lovely women; the thoughts of all rejoiced in love (and) passion.
... with joy indeed and hands placed together he will be able to come here, [and] he will drive away as it were the impurity of passion. 1
With joy indeed and hands placed together he is able to come here, [and] he drives away as it were the impurity of passion. (cf 165)
... having gone inside the (Nyagrodhārāma) monastery, (queen Gautamī) says: Here, this (Cakravartin king) with rank of a Buddha ... by doing right away (?) for the Śākyas ...
(she) says: This ornament of the earth god, with thousand spokes ... of the god Brahman, with the rank of a Buddha, ...
... all women pay homage to the track of the Buddha-god. || Having seen ..., queen Gopikā (says:)
... like ... (surrounded) by Śākya kings at the head of the road of the Banyan tree ...
... certainly shining is my lord and son, or should I say the lord of the Law.
... with respect, having risen from the throne they call out to the queen. ||

p.note: This fragment contains part of the third act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami III, 5a21-6a16. See also 196-7.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 166.
The beginning of the leaf corresponds to MaitrHami 3, 5 a20ff., and its end to MaitrHami 3, 6 a16ff.
The form lcar in the manuscript is a mistake for lcär.
lcar pont: the rare feminine variant of lcär poñś, which is attested e.g. a5, a8, a7, b6, a3, a7.
The same event is lengthily described in MaitrHami 3, 5 b4-5.
ratisupaṃ: a stanza of 4 x 18 (7/7/4) syllables.
Same collocation as in : a4, acle with the verb pälk-; according to the context, TA acle cannot be a proper name.

This fragment contains part of the third act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami III, 5a21-6a16. See also [[Pinault 1999]]: 196-7.

The translation and the following commentary are adapted from [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 166.

a1 ... they all made. || The lay woman says: These Śākya kings ... a2 ... they go to meet the Buddha-god the teacher. || Paṭṭinī says: Now (?), ... a3 (Ceṭikā) says: I too will tell queen Yaśodharā that with the noble Ānanda ... a4 The (lay woman) says: I too will go to meet the Buddha-god the teacher. – All leave. || The interlude a5 (has come to an end.) || ... surrounded ..., carrying the gold-colored cotton cloth in her hands the Śākya queen Mahāprajāpatī Gautamī ... a6 When is the time going to be, when I ... with the rank of Buddha ... this jewel of a garment ... a7 ... lady, this royal (garden) of Nyagrodhārāma ... for the Cakravartin king with the rank of Buddha ... a8 ... queen Gopikā, having looked with (eyes ...) at the Nyagrodhārāma, says: || In the Ratisupa [tune] || b1 ... he made glad (six)ty thousand lovely women; the thoughts of all rejoiced in love (and) passion. b2 ... with joy indeed and hands placed together he will be able to come here, [and] he will drive away as it were the impurity of passion. 1 b3 ... having gone inside the (Nyagrodhārāma) monastery, (queen Gautamī) says: Here, this (Cakravartin king) with rank of a Buddha ... by doing right away (?) for the Śākyas ... b4 (she) says: This ornament of the earth god, with thousand spokes ... of the god Brahman, with the rank of a Buddha, ... b5 ... all women pay homage to the track of the Buddha-god. || Having seen ..., queen Gopikā (says:) b6 ... like ... (surrounded) by Śākya kings at the head of the road of the Banyan tree ... b7 ... certainly shining is my lord and son, or should I say the lord of the Law. b8 ... with respect, having risen from the throne they call out to the queen. ||

a1. The beginning of the leaf corresponds to MaitrHami 3, 5 a20ff., and its end to MaitrHami 3, 6 a16ff.

a2. Cf. MaitrHami 3, 5 a25-26.

a3. Cf. MaitrHami 3, 5 a30f. and b1.

a4. The same event is lengthily described in MaitrHami 3, 5 b4-5.

a5. Cf. MaitrHami 3, 5 b6ff.

a6. Cf. MaitrHami 3, 5 b10ff.

a8. ratisupaṃ: a stanza of 4 x 18 (7/7/4) syllables.

b1. Cf. MaitrHami 3, 5 b21-23.

b3. Cf. MaitrHami 3, 5 b28f.

b4. Cf. MaitrHami 3, 6 a1ff. and a5.

b6. Cf. MaitrHami 3, 6 a10.

The commentary is adapted from [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 166.

a4. The form lcar in the manuscript is a mistake for lcär.

a4. lcar pont: the rare feminine variant of lcär poñś, which is attested e.g. [[A 253]] a5, [[A 297]] a8, [[A 299]] a7, [[A 302]] b6, [[THT 1409.e]] a3, [[YQ I.1]] a7.

b5. Same collocation as in [[YQ III.1]]: a4, acle with the verb pälk-; according to the context, TA acle cannot be a proper name.
